ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Analyze primary sources
How to analyze primary sources and biases in author arguments
What queenship is, the difficulties women in power faced (and still face), how to analyse historical sources, how to write a historical paper
This class helped me learn how to incorporate primary evidence into my history papers. It also helped me with writing history papers, in general.
I became a stronger academic writer, used Chicago style for the first time, became a better at historical reasoning and feminist thought.
I gained insight and knowledge on various queens from a wide array of cultures who ruled by their own right.
I learned so much about queens and female rulers that I had never heard of but also just about the outlook of feminism on society
The difficulty following the legitimacy of Queens throughout history as they gain rule.
I learned how to read lengthy historical pieces and provide insight about them and incorporate them into discussions.
I have developed my ability to triage and read primary and secondary source material.
Women! In History!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very engaging, no cons

The strength of this course was the determination of the professor to see every student succeed and actually learn about the history of the women we studied about. I did not identify any weaknesses in this course. Maybe the leniency with deadlines could have been stricter to help students avoid procrastination.

Wonderful course! Showed women in power, felt very empowering. This side of history doesn't seem often discussed. Discussions were great thanks to the diversity of the class. No suggestions for improvement, really. Maybe if there were more males in the class?
This course is really good at helping you learn how to use and evaluate primary sources. There is also a lot of reading.

Strengths: very in-depth analysis of queens, interesting conversations
Weaknesses: felt slightly rushed towards the end (maybe it would be helpful to put the first paper earlier on, so that the second paper can also be a bit earlier), sometimes I couldn't remember all the queens we talked about, so there could be more reinforcing of the material beyond the one class we talk about a particular queen then kind of do not revisit her

Strengths of this course are the very engaging discussions and the structure which allowed both contemporary and historical perspectives of queens to be analyzed. Feedback on assignments were very helpful and gave direction to improve. The course itself had many strengths and little to no weaknesses across the board.
I think the strengths were that the class was very small which made for good conversations and the only weakness is sometimes there was a lot of reading and it was difficult to get it all done

Strength: groups discussions, interactive

Weakness: only a few assignments so if one does poorly on one, it severely impacts their mark.

Strengths: Engages the students a lot, we would be constantly talking to one another.
Weaknesses: Repetitive conversations
Strengths: relaxed environment, good readings, strong and non-Eurocentric syllabus, multimedia incorporation.

Very well taught , engaging, discussions were interesting and on good topics. What I loved most was mu professor continually asked questions in each class about what we thought. He obviously put lots of effort into making up all those questions for each class and I loved them and appreciated them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I loved the course
Yes, this course is a wonderful course. I would recommend it to anyone interested in learning about ancient queens and the challenges they encountered to legitimize their rule.
Highly! You learn so much about obstacles facing female rule.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I found all of our class discussions and readings super interesting.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in learning specifically about queens. Although other aspects of history were brought up, this course really is a survey of women who ruled and can be limiting at times.

ABSOLUTELY! This course was very engaging and gave me so much more insight into queens who I never heard of who were from so many different backgrounds. This course really helped to see the similarities and differences between queen rulership. This was by far my favorite course at Yale so far and I would definitely take it again!
Yes I would I learned so much and the professor is so nice and helpful
Not unless they're interested in English and history. Marking was hard so more difficult if a stem major.
Yes I would because its a great course for students to really focus on female rulers throughout history and if they love history it'll be a perfect course for them.
Yes -- the course provides a relaxed environment while stimulating growth and learning.
yes
